awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Toward the first novel multi-sensor smart wearable system for hot flash detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is to help women undergoing menopause. Most women undergo menopause, a complex biobehavioral life stage that spans one-third of their life, frequently accompanied by a complex array of symptoms affecting their health, quality of life, relationships, and productivity. The most common and disruptive menopause symptoms are hot flashes, affecting 80% of women, and persisting for up to 10-20 years, with an average duration of 7 years. Unfortunately, there is a lack of adequate support for menopause symptom management, with very few physicians receiving adequate training in menopausal care and unable to provide appropriate care. Importantly, no current solution exists on the market to automatically measure hot flashes and other menopause symptoms over time, a critical limitation in tracking and managing women’s health, and supporting wellness across this challenging life stage. In the U.S., over 50 million women ages 45-55 have hot flashes. The global market for hot flashes is estimated at $9.5B annually and includes alternative, non-hormonal, and hormonal treatment options, with the U.S. accounting for about half-or $4.75B of the total global hot flash market. The proposed technology aims to solve key scientific, technical, and commercial challenges, to build the first novel cost-effective accurate wearable system for menopausal hot flash detection. The proposed wearable system will be an integrated key component of a broader mobile-based digital platform for managing menopause symptoms.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project  Phase I will allow the implementation and evaluation of the effectiveness of using wrist-based multi-sensors, common noninvasive sensors used in commercially available wearable devices, to automatically classify hot flashes, in real-time and free-living conditions (e.g., during sleep and wake, in the presence of noise signals). A combination of synthetic and real-world data will be used to achieve the aims. The system targets >90% accuracy in hot flash classification, across different behavioral, physiological and environmental conditions, against the gold standard method (expert evaluation of fluctuation in sternum skin conductance).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lisa Health aims at developing the first cost-effective, accurate consumer wearable system for menopausal hot flash (HF) detection and characterization. This work has its fundamentals based on the seminal research on menopause and hot flashes performed at SRI International, and is inspired by novel science-backed Lisa Health multi-sensor HFs tracking technology. The NSF STTR Phase I grant allowed us to achieve critical R&D milestones in minimizing scientific/technical and go-to-market risks associated with deploying the first accurate, user-friendly wearable system for passive tracking of HFs. Among the Phase I outcomes, our novel artificial intelligence (AI)-based multi-sensor hot flash algorithm has been adapted and enhanced, achieving high-performance standards in free-living conditions.

The menopause transition can be fraught with physiological and psychosocial symptoms that impact the quality of life and health. It is estimated that by 2025, 1.1 billion women will be postmenopausal, and 80% will have HFs lasting for several years. Ultimately, HFs are the most bothersome and unpredictable menopause symptom. Women have little insight into their HF patterns, triggers, and impact, and the inevitable cascade of related debilitating symptoms, including sleep disturbance, mood issues, fatigue, brain fog, and weight gain. Moreover, women are provided with few strategies to navigate this transitional phase and are given few tools to prevent or treat disruptive symptoms, like HFs. Compounding the problem, in a significant number of women, menopause symptomatology can adversely impact women's health (being linked with increased risk for severe adverse conditions, including cardiovascular diseases, osteoporosis, anxiety, depression, breast cancer, and cognitive decline), quality of life, relationships, and productivity. 

No current technology solution exists on the market to longitudinally track HFs, a critical limitation in managing midlife women's health and supporting healthy aging. By conducting further R&D and commercializing our HF algorithm and mobile app, Lisa Health can revolutionize the industry, positively impacting the mental and physical health, quality of life, productivity, and relationships of millions of women. Women will have a holistic science-backed technology solution for turning a highly prevalent, unpredictable, and impactful symptom into one that can be predicted and controlled. Society would also benefit from a reduction in healthcare costs and gains in productivity. Menopausal symptoms are a global health problem that requires cutting-edge interdisciplinary R&D.
